alert.note: Alert for Arco, Mud Lake Desert; Bear Lake Valley; Bear River Range; Beaverhead, Lemhi Highlands; Big Hole Mountains; Big Lost Highlands, Copper Basin; Blackfoot Mountains; Caribou Range; Centennial Mountains, Island Park; Challis, Pahsimeroi Valleys; Frank Church Wilderness; Franklin, Eastern Oneida Region; Lost River Range; Lost River Valleys; Lower Snake River Plain; Marsh and Arbon Highlands; Shoshone, Lava Beds; Teton Valley; Upper Snake River Plain (Idaho) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued January 02 at 1:11PM MST by NWS Pocatello
info.description: ...SNOW AND WIND MONDAY NIGHT AND TUESDAY... The next round of snow spreads across central and eastern Idaho Monday night through mainly Tuesday morning. New snow accumulations will generally range from a Trace to 3 inches. Expect higher amounts, especially for the Eastern Highlands along the Wyoming Border including the Big Holes and the Wasatch mountains where 3 to 5 inches (with locally higher amounts) are likely. The bigger story will be moderate to strong winds and a higher risk of blowing and drifting snow. This will include snow falling during this period AND the powdery snow already on the ground. Winds will decrease later Tuesday, but the risk of blowing and drifting snow remains especially Monday night into Tuesday morning. A couple areas of concern will be Willow Creek Summit, the Montana Divide, the I-86 corridor from Burley to Pocatello, the I-15 corridor from Pocatello to Fort Hall, I-15 from Fort Hall to Idaho Falls, HWY 26 from Blackfoot to INL, HWY 26 near Antelope Flats, and HWY 33 near Botts. These areas will have moderate to strong winds, which will likely create blowing snow due to existing snow and falling snow.
